title: Beighton railway station
text:
Beighton railway station is a former <a href="train%20station">railway station</a> near the village of <a href="Beighton%2C%20Sheffield">Beighton</a> on the border between <a href="Derbyshire">Derbyshire</a> and <a href="South%20Yorkshire">South Yorkshire</a>, England.
Three stations.
Beighton station existed on three sites at different times:
At the time this station was within <a href="Derbyshire">Derbyshire</a> but following changes in boundaries the site is now within the <a href="City%20of%20Sheffield">City of Sheffield</a>, <a href="South%20Yorkshire">South Yorkshire</a>, England.
Context.
All three stations were in the flood plain of the <a href="River%20Rother%2C%20South%20Yorkshire">River Rother</a>, which repeatedly led to problems. In 1950 these plus the generally poor state of the station building led <a href="British%20Rail">British Rail</a>ways to raise platform levels and undertake other remedial works.
Beighton station closed for the third and final time on 1 November 1954. It has since been demolished.
In 1897 the <a href="Lancashire%2C%20Derbyshire%20and%20East%20Coast%20Railway">Lancashire, Derbyshire and East Coast Railway</a> opened in a branch from <a href="Shirebrook%20North%20railway%20station">Langwith Junction.</a> The original hope had been to join the MS&LR line into <a href="Sheffield%20Victoria%20railway%20station">Sheffield Victoria</a> but it was rebuffed, so a goods yard and connection to the ex-North Midland line at Beighton was built instead, though this did not touch Beighton station. The LD&ECR obtained running rights along the Midland line to Treeton Junction and entered Sheffield via the <a href="Sheffield%20District%20Railway">Sheffield District Railway</a> when it opened in 1900.
In March 2021, the 120-year-old Beighton Station Junction signal cabin, the last remaining relic of the station, was demolished, with control of the lines passing to the <a href="York%20Rail%20Operating%20Centre">York Rail Operating Centre</a>.
